meaning_mnemonic: A 軍艦 is a <kanji>battleship</kanji>, and 島 is an island. Welcome to... <vocabulary>Battleship Island</vocabulary> (go Jurassic Park music).
A <kanji>fake</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is <vocabulary>fake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>counterfeit</vocabulary>.
Something that you <kanji>wrap</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bundle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>.

The に on the end of this word turns <kanji>sincerity</kanji> into an adverb. What's the adverb version of sincerity? It's <vocabulary>sincerely</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>indeed</vocabulary>. It <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> is.

Something <kanji>rare</kanji> is often <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary>. This word could also mean <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary> (of course) and <vocabulary>peculiar</vocabulary> depending on the context.

These days, media often uses this word to describe the way something is unusual, quirky, and funny.
A <kanji>rare</kanji> <kanji>taste</kanji> is a taste you can't have very often, because it's rare. This is a <vocabulary>delicacy</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>rare</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary>. But, this can also mean <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>curious</vocabulary> (as in "odd" curious, not that you're curious about something).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>split</kanji>, but if you split something, you are going <vocabulary>to tear</vocabulary> it or <vocabulary>to rip up</vocabulary> it.

The <kanji>decision</kanji> is <kanji>split</kanji>, causing a <vocabulary>breakdown</vocabulary> in all we've decided. A big ol' <vocabulary>rupture</vocabulary>.

決裂 is a formal word used when talks or relationships totally fall apart. Since it refers to a full-on rupture and sounds dramatic, you'll often see it in news headlines or news reports when negotiations between companies or countries crash and burn.

Things get <kanji>divide</kanji>d and <kanji>split</kanji>. We can just call this a <vocabulary>split</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>division</vocabulary>.

分裂 primarily refers to cells dividing in biology, but it can also figuratively describe an entity or group splitting into separate parts, often due to internal conflict.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>attack</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>attack</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an <vocabulary>attack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assault</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>odd</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an attack you don't expect. This is a <vocabulary>surprise attack</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an <vocabulary>air raid</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>air attack</vocabulary>. Tora tora tora!
A <kanji>reverse</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>counterattack</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>tribute</kanji> I <kanji>offer</kanji> is my <vocabulary>contribution</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 
This word covers a lot of meanings so it can be <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>taste</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>vibe</vocabulary>, or even <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary>.
If something's got <kanji>charm</kanji> and is to your <kanji>taste</kanji>, then it's your <vocabulary>hobby</vocabulary>. Hobbies are activities that you find charming and develop a taste for.

The <kanji>distance</kanji> that is <kanji>detach</kanji>ed from the distance is the <vocabulary>distance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>range</vocabulary>. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range!

A <kanji>door</kanji> <kanji>register</kanji>? Well, a register of people who live behind the same door. In other words, a <vocabulary>family register</vocabulary>. (Think of "door" as shorthand for a house in this case.) Family registers are actually pretty interesting. Look up "koseki" on Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories.
If you're on a <kanji>country</kanji>'s <kanji>register</kanji>, you probably have <vocabulary>nationality</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>citizenship</vocabulary> there. What's your 国籍?

Using <kanji>violence</kanji> I'm going to <kanji>expose</kanji> the truth! This is <vocabulary>disclosure</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>.

This word carries the connotation of something scandalous being revealed, often in a dramatic manner.

I'm going to <kanji>expose</kanji> my <kanji>bone</kanji>s for a second here and be <vocabulary>blunt</vocabulary> with you... this makes sense, because if you're exposing your bones at someone, you're not hiding anything. You're being frank and blunt.
An <kanji>expose</kanji>d <kanji>shop</kanji> is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a <vocabulary>street stall</vocabulary>.

When what you <kanji>expose</kanji> is <kanji>exit</kanji>ed out of hiding, exposed for everything to see... that is <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>. It can also refer to <vocabulary>photographic exposure</vocabulary> too, in case you were wondering.

A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>teacher</kanji> is one who leads his flock around through life. This is a <vocabulary>pastor</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>minister</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>clergyman</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is <vocabulary>pasture land</vocabulary>. It's also a <vocabulary>ranch</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>grass</kanji> is the <vocabulary>pasture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grass</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is a <vocabulary>livestock farm</vocabulary>. It's also a <vocabulary>ranch</vocabulary>. The place where things pasture is this place.
With a <kanji>seal</kanji> we're <kanji>printing</kanji> everything out. The seal is what prints the words on the paper, making this <vocabulary>printing</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>printing</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to print</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> is something that's <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>news</kanji> report is going to be one full of <vocabulary>good news</vocabulary>. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we?
This is the na-adjective version of <kanji>bright</kanji>. The word is <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cheerful</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>wind</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the <vocabulary>tide</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>current</vocabulary>. These days, we usually use this word for the current <vocabulary>trend</vocabulary>s that come in like the tide.
A <kanji>full</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> is a <vocabulary>high tide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>full tide</vocabulary>. That's when the water comes up.
A <kanji>tide</kanji>s <kanji>stream</kanji> is the stream going through the tide. It's the <vocabulary>tide</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>tidal current</vocabulary>.

If you see 即 before a word, you know that it's probably something that happens really fast or instantaneously. That's why this is <vocabulary>immediate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>interest</kanji> in something you didn't have interest in before? Well, time for some <vocabulary>improvisation</vocabulary>, because you're going to have to pretend you have interest in it (since you don't actually).

An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>sit</kanji> is <vocabulary>immediate</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>instantaneous</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself sitting instantly. No time passes between when you were standing and sitting. The instantaneous nature of your sit is definitely... troubling.
An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> is an <vocabulary>instant death</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is the day that's going on this instant. It's the <vocabulary>same day</vocabulary> as now.
It's <kanji>instant</kanji>ly <kanji>effect</kanji>ive! Sounds like something out of Pokemon. This word means <vocabulary>immediate effect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant effect</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that for the word fence in Japanese, フェンス is typically used. 垣 isn't very common but it's sometimes used in literature.

A <kanji>hedge</kanji> (or <kanji>fence</kanji>) <kanji>root</kanji> is where the hedge and fence grow from. What grows from this? Well, it's simply a <vocabulary>hedge</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fence</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>stone</kanji> <kanji>hedge</kanji> is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a <vocabulary>stone wall</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>rights</kanji> and <kanji>might</kanji> over this area. That gives you <vocabulary>authority</vocabulary>.

Take your <kanji>dignity</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it. Your dignity is so stretched! That makes you feel big! That's why this word is <vocabulary>to act big</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be arrogant</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>sphere</kanji> <kanji>might</kanji> is the force you command over a sphere or ball… in this case, a baseball, making this <vocabulary>a pitcher's stuff</vocabulary>. 

If you're not familiar with this baseball term, we recommend giving it a google. In short, it refers to a pitcher's pitches, judged by how inherently hard those pitches are to hit.
<kanji>Dignity</kanji> is a <kanji>strict</kanji> thing. If you're too lenient, you'll lose all your <vocabulary>dignity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>majesty</vocabulary>.
The kanji is <kanji>seal in</kanji>, but the vocab noun version is <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary>. This is simply a seal (not the water kind, the kind you use to seal something with).

When you <kanji>open</kanji> something <kanji>seal</kanji>ed, you're <vocabulary>unsealing</vocabulary> it or <vocabulary>breaking a seal</vocabulary>.

開封 generally refers to opening something sealed, like opening a letter or package.
A <kanji>seal in</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a <vocabulary>sealed letter</vocabulary>.

You've learned that 主義 is "-ism." So what happens when you <kanji>seal</kanji> up everything you <kanji>build</kanji> and keep it for yourself, and make that your -ism? You get <vocabulary>feudalism</vocabulary>. Why? Because feudalism is a system built on the idea that power should be sealed within one group or family. Anyone outside of this sealed system is a vassal to the lord — that's feudalism for you.

<kanji>Seal in</kanji> the <kanji>cylinder</kanji>. This cylinder that is sealed in is an <vocabulary>envelope</vocabulary>. You just have to think back to the day, when things were more like in scroll form. So, a scroll's envelope would have been shaped like a cylinder, making this an <vocabulary>envelope</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You'll see this used to mean <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary> more often than <vocabulary>cylinder</vocabulary>, though.
I show my <kanji>consolation</kanji> by <kanji>apologiz</kanji>ing. This is <vocabulary>consolation</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>consolation</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to console</vocabulary>.

慰める means <vocabulary>to comfort</vocabulary> someone who's experiencing sadness or distress. It can also imply cheering someone up by offering kind words, encouragement, or emotional support.

The best <kanji>consolation</kanji> for someone's <kanji>problem</kanji> is <vocabulary>paying a sympathy call</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>consolation</vocabulary> through a <vocabulary>sympathy visit</vocabulary>.

慰問 is a formal way of saying お見舞い (sympathy visit). It's often used when someone notable, like a celebrity or politician, makes a visit to offer support and comfort to people in difficult situations, like hospital patients, nursing home residents, or those affected by disasters.
You have <kanji>consolation</kanji> so now you can <kanji>relax</kanji>. What a great feeling this is. You now have <vocabulary>solace</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>relaxation</vocabulary>.

Being <kanji>courteous</kanji> is the right <kanji>idea</kanji> if you want to be on <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> terms with others. The more courteous you are to someone (and vice versa), the more a sense of <vocabulary>closeness</vocabulary> grows between you.

懇意 formally describes being on good, cordial terms with someone. You might talk about a colleague you've become friendly with (懇意になった同僚) or a professor who treats you warmly (懇意にしてくれる教授), for example.
A <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji> is a <vocabulary>friendly talk</vocabulary>. We all know that "friendly talks" are never what they seem, though... right?

If you treat someone with <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>intimacy</kanji>, you're probably trying to build a <vocabulary>friendship</vocabulary> with them. Or… maybe something more? No, stop, it's not that kind of intimacy! This word is all about polite friendship and <vocabulary>camaraderie</vocabulary>. Yay for friendship!

懇親 is a formal word that means getting to know someone better in a friendly and sociable manner. You'll most often see it in the word 懇親会 (a casual party for socializing).

A <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji> is an <vocabulary>informal talk</vocabulary> where people gather and discuss something in a friendly way.

懇談 is often used for parent-teacher meetings or community meetings. It's an informal but courteous talk, usually between acquaintances rather than close friends.

The kanji means <kanji>chastise</kanji> but the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to learn by experience</vocabulary>. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).
I will <kanji>chastise</kanji> you and give you <kanji>penalty</kanji>. I do this as a <vocabulary>discipline</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>.
Things that <kanji>chafe</kanji> and <kanji>rub</kanji> have lots of <vocabulary>friction</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>slap</kanji> is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is <vocabulary>sumo wrestling</vocabulary>.
At <kanji>one</kanji> moment it happened <kanji>simultaneous</kanji>ly. It was <vocabulary>simultaneous</vocabulary>. It was <vocabulary>all at once</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>delicious</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. It also means "<vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary>" and "<vocabulary>clever</vocabulary>" as well, because delicious things are skillfully delicious, right?

The <kanji>point</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>principle</vocabulary> of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary> as well.

The parts we <kanji>need</kanji>. The <kanji>point</kanji> of that. That is the <vocabulary>main point</vocabulary>. That is the <vocabulary>essentials</vocabulary>. It's what we need and it's to the point, you know?
The <kanji>point</kanji> to my <kanji>theory</kanji> is the <vocabulary>point of an argument</vocabulary>. That's what I'm trying to say in my theory / argument, man!

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, which tells you it's probably an adjective. The kanji means <kanji>gentle</kanji>, and the adjective version means <vocabulary>soft</vocabulary> — as in a gentle, <vocabulary>tender</vocabulary> kind of softness. Think soft towel, soft hand, soft voice… anything soft in a way that gives you the warm fuzzies.

In reference to the human body, 柔らかい can also mean <vocabulary>flexible</vocabulary>, with an emphasis on supple, effortless movement.
The <kanji>gentle</kanji> <kanji>path</kanji> is, surprisingly, <vocabulary>judo</vocabulary>. Yep, the sport / art based on throwing people around.

A <kanji>gentle</kanji> and <kanji>peace</kanji>ful person is <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tender</vocabulary>.

柔和 is commonly used in literature to describe someone whose nature or features express <vocabulary>gentleness</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sink</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sink</vocabulary>.

On a literal level, 沈む refers to physical sinking — a boat sinking into the water or someone's foot sinking into the mud, for example. However, it can also be used metaphorically to talk about things like the sun setting (太陽が沈む), a nation falling into decline (国が沈む), or even someone "sinking" into a depressed mood (気分が沈む).
<kanji>Sink</kanji> and <kanji>stagnate</kanji>. Imagine something is doing just that. It is in the state of <vocabulary>stagnation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inactivity</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is a <vocabulary>marshy rice field</vocabulary>. This is just a rice paddy in marshy form.

In modern language, 沼田 is mostly used as a place name or surname, such as <vocabulary>Numata</vocabulary> City in Gunma Prefecture or someone with the last name Numata.
A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>swamp</kanji> is a <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>marsh</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Relax</kanji> in <kanji>peace</kanji>. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly <vocabulary>peace</vocabulary>. You feel <vocabulary>security</vocabulary> too.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>destroy</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to destroy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to annihilate</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Destroy</kanji> to <kanji>death</kanji>. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your <vocabulary>downfall</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ruin</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Slap</kanji> that bug and <kanji>destroy</kanji> it. Haha! I slapped all the bugs away. This is <vocabulary>extermination</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Extinction</kanji> where everything is <kanji>destroy</kanji>ed is <vocabulary>extinction</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>break</kanji> and <kanji>destroy</kanji> something, that is <vocabulary>destruction</vocabulary>. That is <vocabulary>annihilation</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>illusion</kanji> is <kanji>destroy</kanji>ed. If your illusion is destroyed, that is <vocabulary>disillusionment</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Nourishing</kanji> and <kanji>foster</kanji>ing. The thing that gives you this is <vocabulary>nourishment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nutrition</vocabulary>.

滋養 is a formal and somewhat old-fashioned word. It's mostly used in writing to describe nutritious foods or the health benefits of supplements, tonics, or energy drinks.
A <kanji>high</kanji> <kanji>furnace</kanji> is one that's particularly hot and blasty. This is a <vocabulary>blast furnace</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>furnace</kanji> is a furnace for warming you and other things. This is a <vocabulary>fireplace</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hearth</vocabulary> or even a <vocabulary>stove</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>furnace</kanji> <kanji>heart</kanji> is the heart of the furnace. The heart of this particular furnace, the one we're talking about here, is the <vocabulary>nuclear reactor core</vocabulary>.
If a 原子 is an <kanji>atom</kanji> and a 炉 is a <kanji>furnace</kanji>, what is a furnace that has atoms? It is an <vocabulary>atomic reactor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nuclear reactor</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>harp</kanji>, at least in Japan, is the <vocabulary>koto</vocabulary>, also known (to us) as the <vocabulary>Japanese harp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese zither</vocabulary>.

If 伺う is "to inquire" or "to visit" then the noun version would be a polite way to say <vocabulary>inquiry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>enquiry</vocabulary>. In other words, a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary>. It can also mean a <vocabulary>visit</vocabulary>.
Remember 群れる, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conceal</kanji>, but as a verb, this word means <vocabulary>to go under</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pass through</vocabulary>. Most commonly, this word means <vocabulary>to dive underwater</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go underground</vocabulary>. Can you see why the kanji for conceal kind of makes sense in these cases? If you're underwater or underground, no one can see you!
A <kanji>fluid</kanji> <kanji>crystal</kanji> is a <vocabulary>liquid crystal</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>crystal</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>crystal</vocabulary>. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.

In order to use a <kanji>house counter</kanji> in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find <vocabulary>eaves</vocabulary>. And all those eaves together <vocabulary>stand in a row</vocabulary>.

Remember how 慰謝 means "consolation?" Add <kanji>fee</kanji> to that and you get <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>consolation money</vocabulary>, depending on the situation.

慰謝料 refers to compensation for mental or emotional distress. It covers damages for non-physical harm, such as emotional pain in divorce settlements, affairs, or accidents, where the victim seeks financial redress for their distress.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You learned another vocabulary word 札 as "amulet," but this is a special <kanji>honorable</kanji> <vocabulary>amulet</vocabulary>. It's a <vocabulary>talisman</vocabulary>.

Ah yes, <kanji>wet</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for <vocabulary>false accusations</vocabulary>. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason.
This may look like a verb at first, but it's actually the adverb version of the adjective 凄い. When something is <kanji>awful</kanji> it's usually <vocabulary>awfully</vocabulary> awful.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. The kanji means <kanji>hoist</kanji>, but the verb most commonly means <vocabulary>to be fried up</vocabulary>, ready to eat. Imagine something being hoisted up onto the table because it's fried and ready to eat. The verb can also mean, more logically, <vocabulary>to be up</vocabulary>.
